ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to immerse myself into research as an undergraduate and understand the project that I was working on in its broader context.
It gave me a great opportunity to engage in my research and write a paper scientifically explaining what I did.

I further developed my research skills and learned how to think more as a scientist. It was also helpful to put together a proposal and to write a research paper about what we had done though the semester.
I improved my skills in techniques including cell culture and qPCR. I also improved in presenting my research and translating what my project is about into language that everyone can understand.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: the course is great for students beginning to conduct their own independent research, allowing flexibility in scheduling. No weaknesses
I loved doing research for credit!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Good class if you want to get credit for doing research in the lab.
Yes! It's a great way to stay involved in your lab during the semester.

I would recommend this course to another student who wants to continue doing research in a lab they worked in over the summer since it forces you to cut out time in your schedule to work on your research project.
